verses.text: The word of the LORD came to me, saying,
verses.comment: Similar to previous prophetic sessions (see Ezekiel 26:1), the passage begins with a divine revelation directed to Ezekiel.

verses.text: Son of man, raise a lamentation for Tyre,
verses.comment: Lamentations are poetic forms mourning over destruction, often used for cities as in Lamentations or Isaiah 14. The lament here signals spiritual warning for all nations that rely on wealth or pride over God.

verses.text: and say to Tyre, who dwells at the entrances to the sea, the merchant of the peoples to many coastlands: 'Thus says the Lord GOD: "O Tyre, you have said, ‘I am perfect in beauty.’"
verses.comment: Tyre is personified as proud and self-sufficient, which contrasts with the biblical theme that true beauty comes from God. See how this pride parallels at the tower of Babel (Genesis 11:4).

verses.text: Your borders are in the heart of the seas; your builders made your beauty perfect.
verses.comment: The city's wealth and skill are sourced in human craftsmanship, echoing the spiritual danger of trusting created things above the Creator (Romans 1:25).

verses.text: They made all your planks of fir trees from Senir; they took a cedar from Lebanon to make a mast for you.
verses.comment: Materials from Lebanon symbolize the finest craftsmanship, also found in the construction of the Temple (1 Kings 5:6-10). The mention here shows the link between commerce, art, and false senses of security.

verses.text: They made your oars of oaks from Bashan; they made your deck of cypress wood inlaid with ivory from the coasts of Cyprus.
verses.comment: The careful construction echoes Temple imagery, reinforcing the biblical idea that nothing man-made is immune to judgment, no matter how beautiful (cf. Matthew 24:2 about the Temple).

verses.text: Your sail was made of fine embroidered linen from Egypt, serving as your banner; blue and purple from the coasts of Elishah were your awning.
verses.comment: Blue and purple were costly dyes used for priestly and royal robes (Exodus 28:5), linking the splendor of Tyre to religious imagery. This subtly hints at the role of beauty and ritual in worship.

verses.text: The inhabitants of Sidon and Arvad were your rowers; your skilled men, O Tyre, were within you; they were your pilots.
verses.comment: Tyre's reliance on skilled men from many nations shows both its international prestige and the ultimate futility of human alliances when facing divine judgment.

verses.text: The elders of Gebal and its skilled men were within you, caulking your seams; all the ships of the sea with their mariners were with you to trade for your merchandise.
verses.comment: Symbolically, the detail of caulking recalls Noah’s Ark—a vessel made secure by God's command (Genesis 6:14). Here, it’s human wisdom, not God’s word, that sustains Tyre.

verses.text: Those from Persia, Lud, and Put were in your army, serving as your men of war; they hung shield and helmet in you, they gave you splendor.
verses.comment: Tyre’s military alliances illustrate reliance on external power. Spiritually, this links to warnings elsewhere against trusting in armies over God (Psalm 20:7).

verses.text: Men of Arvad were on your walls all around, and valiant men were in your towers; they hung their shields on your walls all around; they made your beauty perfect.
verses.comment: The fortification and display of strength echo the effort to protect glory—yet all human effort is destined to end (cf. Genesis 11:1-9).

verses.text: Tarshish traded with you because of your great wealth of every kind; silver, iron, tin, and lead they exchanged for your wares.
verses.comment: Tyre’s partnerships demonstrate global reach and echo commercial themes found throughout Scripture (for example, the merchants in Revelation 18:3).

verses.text: Javan, Tubal, and Meshech traded with you; they exchanged human beings and vessels of bronze for your goods.
verses.comment: The practice of trafficking in people already stands condemned by later biblical teaching (see Philemon 1:16), foreshadowing Christian emphasis on the dignity of all people.

verses.text: From the house of Togarmah they brought horses, war horses, and mules for your merchandise.
verses.comment: Animal trade, here as in ancient Israel, underscores wealth but also the dangers of alliances built on material gain rather than trust in God.

verses.text: The men of Dedan traded with you. Many coastlands were your own special markets; ivory tusks and ebony they brought as payment.
verses.comment: Tyre’s luxury trade points toward New Testament warnings about the temptations of riches (1 Timothy 6:9-10).

verses.text: Edom traded with you for your many goods; turquoise, purple fabric, embroidered work, fine linen, coral, and rubies they exchanged for your wares.
verses.comment: The extravagant goods signal both authentic beauty and the spiritual dangers of excess. In the spiritual tradition, purple and fine linen also signify readiness for sacred service (Luke 16:19).

verses.text: Judah and the land of Israel traded with you; they exchanged wheat from Minnith, early figs, honey, oil, and balm for your merchandise.
verses.comment: Israel’s trade with Tyre reminds us that God’s people are called to interact with other nations, but always with fidelity to divine law (see Exodus 23:32).

verses.text: Damascus traded wine from Helbon and white wool with you, because of your abundant wealth.
verses.comment: Wine is often used as a symbol of joy and blessing in Scripture, but also of judgment if abused (cf. Psalm 75:8).

verses.text: Vedan and Javan from Uzal traded for your wares; wrought iron, cassia, and sweet cane were together among your merchandise.
verses.comment: The luxury goods demonstrate Tyre’s global importance. Symbolically, incense (sweet cane) is later linked to prayer (Revelation 8:4), showing spiritual realities behind material trade.

verses.text: Dedan traded in saddle blankets with you.
verses.comment: Everyday goods, even those not luxurious, are nurtured by Tyre’s commercial empire. This recalls the stewardship principle in all of life (Luke 19:13).

verses.text: Arabia and all the princes of Kedar traded for your lambs, rams, and goats; in these, they traded with you.
verses.comment: Sheep and goats are imagery later taken up by Jesus in parable for spiritual meaning (Matthew 25:32).

verses.text: The traders of Sheba and Raamah traded with you; they provided the choicest spices, all kinds of precious stones, and gold in exchange for your goods.
verses.comment: The Magi’s later gifts to the Messiah echo these luxurious items, showing that worldly wealth ultimately finds its true use in worship (Matthew 2:11).

verses.text: Haran, Canneh, Eden, traders of Sheba, Assyria, and Chilmad traded with you.
verses.comment: Eden here is a region, but evokes spiritual memory of paradise lost, foreshadowing the restoration promised in Christ (Revelation 22:2).

verses.text: They traded with you in garments of blue and embroidered work, fine clothes, rich carpets bound and tightly woven, which were among your merchandise.
verses.comment: Linen and blue are priestly colors, prefiguring the spiritual garments put on by Christ’s followers (Revelation 19:8).

verses.text: The ships of Tarshish traveled for you with your merchandise. You were filled and heavily laden in the heart of the seas.
verses.comment: Tarshish symbolized the ends of the earth (Psalm 72:10), hinting at the eventual universality of God’s kingdom (also see Acts 1:8).

verses.text: Your rowers have brought you out into the deep waters; the east wind has broken you in the heart of the seas.
verses.comment: The sea is often an image of chaos or judgment, as in the Red Sea story (Exodus 14:21-28). Here Tyre is undone by forces beyond human control.

verses.text: Your riches, wares, merchandise, your mariners, pilots, caulkers, your dealers in merchandise, all your men of war who are in you, and all your company that is in your midst, will sink into the heart of the seas on the day of your fall.
verses.comment: This prefigures the destruction of 'Babylon' in Revelation—worldly splendor cannot save from divine judgment.

verses.text: At the sound of the cry of your pilots the fields tremble.
verses.comment: The distress of the pilots illustrates the impact of spiritual and national disaster. Compare to the lamentation over Jerusalem (Lamentations 2:11).

verses.text: All who handle the oar, the mariners and all the pilots of the sea, will come down from their ships and stand on the land.
verses.comment: Even those skilled in navigating the seas cannot escape when God acts. This is a recurring biblical theme, as in Jonah’s story (Jonah 1:15).

verses.text: They will raise their voices and cry bitterly over you, they will cast dust on their heads, they will wallow in ashes;
verses.comment: The acts of mourning reflect deep loss, seen elsewhere as signs of repentance (Matthew 11:21).

verses.text: they will shave their heads for you and put on sackcloth; they will weep for you in bitterness of soul with bitter mourning.
verses.comment: Rites of mourning are intense, marking true repentance, which remains essential in the life of faith (James 4:9).

verses.text: In their wailing they will raise a lamentation for you and lament over you: ‘Who is like Tyre, like one destroyed in the middle of the sea?’
verses.comment: The phrase 'Who is like...' is later used for God (Micah 7:18), pointing us to the danger of elevating creation above Creator.

verses.text: When your merchandise went out on the seas, you satisfied many peoples; with your abundant wealth and your goods you enriched the kings of the earth.
verses.comment: Earthly riches grant temporary satisfaction but cannot save, echoing Christ’s words (Matthew 16:26).

verses.text: But you are wrecked by the seas, in the depths of the waters; your merchandise and all your company in your midst have fallen.
verses.comment: The fall of Tyre foreshadows the spiritual truth found through salvation history: judgment comes to all cities and systems opposing God’s kingdom.

verses.text: All the inhabitants of the coastlands are appalled at you; their kings are horribly afraid; their faces are troubled.
verses.comment: The reaction of the nations shows the far-reaching consequences of turning from God. See how nations tremble before the Lord (Psalm 2:11).

verses.text: The merchants among the peoples hiss at you; you have come to a horrible end, and shall be no more forever.’”
verses.comment: Tyre’s final end highlights the fleeting nature of human glory apart from God. The ultimate fulfillment comes through God’s everlasting kingdom in Christ (Revelation 21:1-4), where the faithful are brought together from all nations in worship that endures forever.
